And that hierarchy, you could call it patriarchy if you want, because it does tend to have a certain masculine characteristic because it's public. It has a certain amount of use of authority, all of that. But the thing is, is that that hierarchy cannot exist without the space in which to exist. If you try to make them into patriarchy, then you're. You're. You're actually acting against the power of this feminine symbolism. Like, if you, if you want the feminine symbolism to act like an authority in the world with a sword and like, beating there like, that's, that's not. That's just it. You need. For any hierarchy to exist, you need a space in which it exists, you know, but that space also is given form that they are given an answer or given some structure through what you would call patriarchy or a hierarchy. The classic image is the image of Elijah who goes into the cave and is, you know, he's distraught and he's trying to understand the will of God. And, and there's this storm and there's tempest, and it says God is not in the storm. And the tempest then finally says, there's the still soft voice. And then he hears God in the still soft voice. There definitely is, let's say, the aspect of rigor which you find in the Old Testament, the kind of more, let's say, the harsher aspect of reality is there trials. It's like no reality has. There's a certain amount of objectivity to the way reality lays itself out. And if you, if you don't adhere to that, then you're going to. episode_id: SW - #087 - 2020-01-08 - Benjamin Boyce - Masculine Actualities and Feminine Possibilities
speaker: Jonathan Pageau

episode_id: SW - #087 - 2020-01-08 - Benjamin Boyce - Masculine Actualities and Feminine Possibilities
speaker: Benjamin Boyce
text: Do you think that it was necessary to kind of clean up all the symbolic. The problem with symbolic thinking is that it can get really messy and get really associative. episode_id: SW - #087 - 2020-01-08 - Benjamin Boyce - Masculine Actualities and Feminine Possibilities
speaker: Jonathan Pageau
text: I think yes, if what you want is to make better pavement or to have energy efficient windows or whatever, like whatever it is that technology does and science does. And so if you, and so if you just try to eliminate that when analyzing a human person, then you, then you run into serious problems. And so although, let's say analogical thinking can be problematic, can be messy, it's also the way in which you can move up the different levels, like the different levels of being. If you want to understand a, let's say how a group works, or a city or a nation. At the end, they might think that it's only the person answering the questions who had a place, who was discussing, but they can't see the opening, like you said, the pre. Logical. The opening of the space. They don't see how without that, things would be completely different. And so it is an extremely powerful thing. So if you look at my videos, like you said, we're secret feminists. It's like if you look at the logo for my YouTube channel. It took a while for people to realize that it's actually the creation of Eve. That's the story. That's the image. You have to see that it's like. Because I think that the modern world is overly masculine. It's too masculine. It's actually the feminine which is disappearing from the world. And so I think that. I think that that's a really dangerous place to be. And we see it in the reduction of community, the destruction of private space. All of this is being eclipsed. Everything is becoming public. Everything is becoming a form of showing yourself voyeurism and showing yourself. Everything is that. And so I think helping to open up the feminine space in a reverential way, I think is something that is vulnerable. Yeah.
